text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot Thai kitchen so today I 
want to share with you one of the most nostalgic

treats ever these are my childhood snack that 
I used to love they're so addictive I haven't

add them for years and then not too long ago I 
ran into them on the internet and I thought oh

my god these these are so good I've missed them 
and I thought huh I wonder if they are hard to

make it turns out they are not they're super 
easy and so I want to share them with you and

this is like a peek into like Thai children's 
food culture I guess even though adults also

enjoy them these are called - tua krob keaw  tua 
peanuts krob means crunchy keaw means glass which

I don't know why it's part of the name it just is 
they're candied peanuts with a little bit of like

a cocoa flavor with sesame seeds on the outside 
super good super addictive and makes really great

edible gift actually alright let's get started 
obviously you're going to need peanuts but not

any kind of peanuts you want raw skin on peanuts 
just like these can be hard to find so you want to

go to an Asian grocery store that's where you're 
gonna find raw skin on peanuts and the reason why

you want the skin is without the skin say you get 
something like this the two halves of the peanuts

will split apart really easily they already 
like half of them in the bags already split

and if they're not by the time you done stirring 
them you know they're gonna be broken and you

they're not gonna get round peanuts you're gonna 
get broken ones which will then ruin the surface

area to volume ratio of your candied peanuts 
Jesus don't want to go there okay I also want

to point out that you have option for size some 
peanuts are bigger than others I would go for

the bigger ones just because then it's you know 
then you have more peanut per piece as opposed to

less peanut and more sugar per piece again it's 
all about the surface area to volume ratio the

candy crust versus peanut meat ratio you can 
also not use peanuts for this you can also do

whatever nuts you want I've done it with almonds 
and worked out really what I think almonds worked

out the best cuz they're the crunchiest okay 
so that's peanut once you get them spread them

out onto a plate and you want to take some time 
to pick out some bad ones and there's usually a

few bad ones such as this guy over here see this I 
know there's something there's something not right

with this guy I know what it is I just don't want 
to eat that okay and there's usually not much but

you just don't want disease looking peanuts I 
mean I am sure these are not poisonous I just

don't know okay and then you can wash these if you 
like but if they look pretty clean they don't you

dusty then there's really no need to wash them 
at the heck look at this so that's that other

ingredients that I want to talk about sesame seeds 
super important you want to have this is the part

that makes these so like aromatic and flavorful 
the flavor of toasted white sesame seeds now I

typically buy sesame seeds raw and then I toast 
it myself we just put in a dry sautee pan stir

it around over medium medium-high heat until they 
turn golden but then I bought these not knowing

that they were already toasted because there's 
no English on the back and I just assumed that

these were raw but they are not a couple more 
ingredients Ovaltine powder so this is what's

gonna give them a little bit of color and a 
little bit of cocoa flavor Ovaltine is a malted

drink chocolate malt drink powder mix there you 
go if you're in Asia you definitely know what

I'm talking about but if you don't have it you 
can just use cocoa powder that'll do the trick

as well but just use half the amount because 
this is has a lot of sugar in it as well right

it's not just cocoa with instant coffee this 
is something that I like to add is completely

optional but I think it adds a little bit of like 
a smoky sophisticated nasai in these peanuts you

got kids you don't want them to be helped up on 
hyped up on caffeine you can skip it okay it's

pretty simple let's get cooking so the choice 
of cookware for this is quite important you

want something you're gonna be stirring this with 
gusto okay hot peanuts coated in hot sugar you do

want something that's gonna allow the peanuts to 
jump out you want to be able to stir vigorously

without worrying about that so something with a 
little depth a sort of bull shape like this is

perfect nothing shallow trust me you're going to 
be cursing throughout the process if you're trying

to stir hot peanuts in like a saute pan okay so in 
here I'm going to turn heat on just to low medium

to medium-low everything is going to be done in 
the pan so sugar is going in and then I'm gonna

add some water now I'm not making a lot because 
these are too addictive and if I make a lot I'm

gonna eat them all and that's just bad news oh 
man I'm also gonna add coconut milk it's gonna

be the flavor and the fat makes them really good 
a little bit of my Ovaltine powder here just a

couple of teaspoons yeah and then a touch of my 
Nescafe coffee powder you can use the Starbucks

via but don't use too much because those one are 
really fine so just need like a touch gonna stir

that get everything to mix together if some of 
the coffee powder looks stubborn don't worry it

will dissolve eventually and you can probably 
use brown sugar or palm sugar for this but to

stay true to the authenticity of these peanuts 
you want to use white sugar also these are like

cheap you know cheap streetside snacks you don't 
want to use palm sugar that's expensive my sugar

is disolved I'm going to add all of my peanuts now 
if you are making a lot you may not need to scale

up the amount of water proportionally because the 
only purpose of the water right now is to sort of

almost submerge the peanuts so that you can cook 
the peanut through because we're starting with

raw peanuts right and so if you're using a lot of 
peanuts just add enough water so that it comes up

to the level of the peanuts and that's it and then 
I'm gonna keep the heat low and in the beginning

you don't really have to be here stirring all 
that often because it's just kind of boiling at

this point but once the syrup starts to thicken 
that's when you do not want to walk away you want

to be stirring because you don't want any sure 
burning to the bottom you want the peanuts to

evenly coat and things can really change quickly 
at that stage so be careful so it's been maybe

like eight ten minutes something like that it's 
starting to thicken now this is when you want to

be stirring all the time because it can go from 
this to really syrupy and dry faster than you

think it's smelling so good right now I'm telling 
you the combination of coffee and coconut milk mmm

there's just something about that reminds me of 
my mocha toffee cake recipe if you haven't checked

that out and you're a baker you gotta check it 
out this smell is reminding me of that cake okay

look at this look at this oh my god looks so 
good this walk by the way is a Korean walk it's

called Korea King I got this from Thailand won 
it at like a family holiday raffle okay this is

important right here the sugar is getting so thick 
now what's about to happen is it going to start

to crystallize okay do not panic it will look 
completely wrong but it is right but definitely

this is where you do not stop stirring preferably 
you're not talking and filming at the same time

okay see this is starting to get a little bit 
powdery now okay this is good this is good I

get nervous when it comes to this part because 
it's like ah things is happening now is gonna

look like wet sand totally normal keep going and 
now it's really dry and powdery this is where you

want to add your salt you want to use fine salt 
so that it spreads more easily no coarse salt

and could I have added the salt in the beginning 
you could have but I actually like when the salt

is sort of at the surface you get that hit of 
saltiness what's about to happen if I added the

sesame seeds now they won't stick because it's 
dry but if I keep going all that service sugar is

going to start to dissolve again and then the nuts 
are going to get wet that's when you throw in the

sesame seeds so that they have something to stick 
on you don't want the sugar to remelt back too

fast and then become liquid again because then it 
becomes liquid then it just runs off the peanuts

there you go you can see that the Lewis sugar is 
now starting to clump together oh no I run out

of gas Adam quick that's why it was taking a long 
time because it was running out now I'm gonna turn

it on and it's gonna be an inferno I'm not really 
careful okay back in business starting to see some

wetness on the peanuts I'm waiting for all the 
peanuts to have some wet spots for the sesame to

stick on alright here we go we're close we're 
close we're close now I see wet spots on most

of them I'm gonna go in with my sesame seeds and 
then toss I'm actually gonna turn the heat off now

I'm just gonna use the residual heat of what's in 
my pen to do the rest starting to smoke a bit as

you can see nice this is perfect timing see haha 
okay now you want to have a sheet pan with either

silicone or parchment ready because you want to 
get it out and onto the pan quickly and spread

them out so they don't stick together another 
reason why you really don't want these to get too

wet before you add the sesame seeds is if they get 
too wet and the sugar starts to become liquid they

will stick together it'll clump up together a lot 
and also that hardened liquefied sugar is harder

so this is crunchy and a little bit airy because 
the sugar is crystallized still but once it really

Co Faiz and becomes smooth that's when you get 
hard bits of sugar and that's it don't eat these

right now it'll burn your tongue off let them cool 
completely and then we'll have them look at these

these are all cool now they look so good they 
look just like I remember them when I was a kid

I just want to point out see these naked peanuts 
okay I should have mentioned this earlier actually

the main reason why you don't want to use no skins 
peanut is the fact that the sugar is not going to

stay on very well because they're so slippery as 
you can see here so these you're gonna get a few

where the skin comes off while you're cooking 
it so this is completely normal so these hats

getting's on and they just slipped off during 
the process and also you're gonna get these

like little clusters of just sugar these are good 
like these little bits of crunchy sugar with just

so much sesame on it and to store these I think in 
the little mason jar is good because it's airtight

and also it looks really cute it makes a great 
gift so if you wanted to pack them up you just

put them in here how cute is that put a little bow 
on it off you go okay but let's eat it or you can

smell that little bit of coffee aroma the copy is 
optional but I highly recommend it so crunchy and

you cannot have just one not possible perfectly 
sweet not too sweet with a touch of saltiness but

most importantly it is not hard if you've ever had 
like candied something or other and then the sugar

is so hard on your teeth you feel like you're 
gonna break up to it this is not it and the key

to making sure they are not hard is you don't let 
the sugar re melt too far when the sugar is sort

of like rough and a little bit powdery like this 
that's when the sugar is crunchy my only advice

is if you make it you put it away you put most 
of it away and you leave just as much as you're

willing to eat on the counter because I promise 
you eat all of it in no time they give it's just

sitting there and you're walking around the house 
every time you're gonna eat it you're gonna here

it is it is like I've been there that's why I'm 
only making this much okay you've been born so
